With the budget still in the balance this seems highly unlikely.
Again "time to resolution" slashes my probability of unlikely outcome.

https://eur-lex.europa.eu/summary/glossary/enhanced_cooperation.html ENHANCED COOPERATION Enhanced cooperation is a procedure where a minimum of 9 EU countries are allowed to establish advanced integration or cooperation in an area within EU structures but without the other EU countries being involved. This allows them to move at different speeds and towards different goals than those outside the enhanced cooperation areas. The procedure is designed to overcome paralysis, where a proposal is blocked by an individual country or a small group of countries who do not wish to be part of the initiative. It does not, however, allow for an extension of powers outside those permitted by the EU Treaties. Authorisation to proceed with the enhanced cooperation is granted by the Council, on a proposal from the Commission and after obtaining the consent of the European Parliament. As of February 2013, this procedure was being used in the fields of divorce law, and patents, and is approved for the field of a financial transaction tax.
The EU has other concerns. This doesn't look to be a priority based upon rhe main topics under discussion.

"...on Monday when Hungary and Poland blocked the stimulus plan and the broader budget, cracking open one of the bloc’s most persistent, existential divisions over what a European Union democracy looks like ... at the insistence of the European Parliament, which must approve spending, the budget bill passed earlier this month included language making the funds contingent on rule of law standards that the E.U. considers fundamental to its values. The item was clearly aimed at the Hungarian and Polish governments, which have defiantly chipped away at independent judiciaries among other democratic norms." https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/16/world/europe/eu-stimulus-poland-hungary.html The European Parliament has clearly shown some willingness to try to hold Viktor Orban accountable for his authoritarian consolidation of power in Hungary.  For an Article 7.1 determination to be made: "The mechanism begins with a proposal to find a 'Clear Risk of Serious Breach' of EU values either by the Commission, the Parliament or one-third of member states. This is then approved by a two-thirds majority in Parliament. The accused country is then called to answer to the Council, which may then issue recommendations and vote by four-fifths to identify a breach" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Article_7_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union So the most likely scenario as of now is the following: the European Parliament finds a 'Clear Risk of Serious Breach' and then approves this by a two-thirds majority.  Then, four-fifths of the Council votes to identify a breach. This does not seem all that unlikely. I think the crowd forecast (1%) is definitely too low.

This [1] is an excellent read on how Viktor Orban has escaped facing any serious consequences from the EU for his undermining of Hungary's rule of law and democratic institutions. Here's a part that's especially relevant to this question:  "Hungary presents a puzzle for the EU, as it prepares to roll out its first rule of law report assessing the bloc’s 27 member countries on September 30 ... few expect it [the EU] to stop Orbán’s abuse of the rule of law ... while it [the EU] formally triggered Article 7 proceedings against Warsaw in 2017, it did not do so for Budapest ... It was only after the European Parliament acted in 2018 and formally triggered Article 7 that proceedings were started against Hungary ... There is a sense in the Council — even among some governments that dislike Orbán's policies — that Article 7 should be avoided. The worry is that isolating a member country could put further pressure on the bloc even as it is still recovering from the United Kingdom’s decision to leave" [2]. If the past is any guide, then it's very unlikely that Article 7 proceedings against Hungary will be completed. But note that this question asks about Article 7.1, for which the bar is not that high: "The mechanism begins with a proposal to find a 'Clear Risk of Serious Breach' of EU values either by the Commission, the Parliament or one-third of member states. This is then approved by a two-thirds majority in Parliament. The accused country is then called to answer to the Council, which may then issue recommendations and vote by four-fifths to identify a breach" [3]. If nothing happens after the release of the EU's rule of law report on 30 September, then I'll revise significantly downward. [1, 2] https://www.politico.eu/article/how-viktor-orban-broke-the-eu-and-got-away-with-it-hungary-rule-of-law/
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Article_7_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union

A demand by the European Parliament’s Civil Liberties Committee, advanced by Dutch Green MEP Judith Sargentini to invoke Article 7 against Hungary for ‘weakening of the Constitutional Court and the judiciary, corruption, restrictions on freedom of expression, assembly and intimidation of the media, non-governmental organizations and research institutions.’  
Article 7(1), which is a determination rather than an action, would see a formal warning given to the country accused of violating fundamental rights.
There does appear to be reticence by the EU to punish Orban due to political considerations.  Fidesz is the political party of the Hungarian President Orban and belongs to the centre right European People’s Party (EPP) grouping within the European Parliament that includes Merkel and Veradkar. They do not want to isolate Orban due to his ability to supply votes and therefore maintaining the group’s influence.
This was in April 2018.
In September 2018, the Eu Parliament voted to issue Article 7 (1) to Hungary, which opens the door to sanctions, but Article 7 can only be enacted if all the EU members agree, which is problematical as Poland is in a similar position to Hungary and they will support each other.
The EU is currently distracted by the Coronavirus pandemic, Brexit and the resultant budgetary woes.
Hungary has also become the largest recipient of EU aid to combat the outcomes of the pandemic even though the country suffered less than others within the EU Community.
Therefore, the chances of Hungary being subjected to Article 7 would appear to be slim.

With Orban's consent, Hungary's parliament has voted to end Orban's emergency rule-by-decree powers [1,2]. However, this is not a complete rollback of the emergency powers that have empowered Orban — "An analysis by Karoly Eotvos Institute, a democracy watchdog in Budapest, concluded that the legislation approved on Tuesday had no intention of restoring Hungary’s pre-coronavirus legal order, 'but rather creates a legal basis for the use of newer extraordinary and unlimited government powers.'" [2] However, the EU was pretty quiet when Orban was able to rule by decree — it thus seems unlikely that they'll take any significant action against Orban, especially given that some (but not all) of his newly acquired powers have been rolled back. Germany will take over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union on 01 July 2020 and will likely position themselves as the "Guardians of the Treaties" ahead of other new issues raised by trouble-making nations in the EU. In the conclusion, there is likely tough talk from October on (since Germany is seeing the beginning of their general election rallies) but no real confrontation. However, Hungary will keep testing the core-European nations' patience on every occasion. Clashes towards year end 2020 are becoming more likely, and so is the risk of a escalation for real.

Hungary's government appears to be preparing to scale back Orban's emergency powers (presumably with Orban's consent): "The Hungarian government plans to bring to an end controversial emergency legislation, which some critics described as creating the EU’s first dictatorship. Hungary’s justice minister, Judit Varga, announced on Tuesday that she would submit legislation to parliament imminently that would bring an end to the so-called 'state of danger' on 20 June. While in force, it has allowed the country’s prime minister, Viktor Orbán, to rule by decree, and had no fixed cut-off date." https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/may/26/hungarian-government-to-end-orbans-rule-by-decree-legislation-emergency-coronavirus I think if Hungary follows through on scaling back these measures then we can expect that the EU will not make an Article 7.1 determination.

Article 7.1: The mechanism begins with a proposal to find a "Clear Risk of Serious Breach" of EU values either by the Commission, the Parliament or one-third of member states. This is then approved by a two-thirds majority in Parliament. The accused country is then called to answer to the Council, which may then issue recommendations and vote by four-fifths to identify a breach. 
It tends to be a long process so even if it happens not likely to come to a quick resolution. 
https://www.theparliamentmagazine.eu/articles/news/pressure-mounts-eu-take-%E2%80%9Cswift%E2%80%9D-action-against-hungary

With Corona crises not being "over" by end 2020 this gives those forces in Europe support (i.e. an excuse) that do not want to trigger anything against Hungary (countries like Poland but also the conservative fraction)

Activating Article 7 has been previously debated for use against Austria, France and Romania, but official recommendations were never made. Currently, both Hungary and Poland are being discussed, but motions have not yet been put forth. (0/5; 0% base odds) Hungary and Poland can count on each other's veto votes. Hungary is also supported in the council by Spain and the Czech Republic, however, Hungary's conservative UK supporters have left the council, increasing odds somewhat. Still, it remains highly unlikely, as it would strain the already tense political relations, and the Corona-induced state of emergency is, for the time being, a sound justification.

They can make a determination they broke the rules without unanimity. They can sanction without unanimous vote but not suspend voting rights. Usually they send a group to investigate. That takes awhile. Under Coronavirus probably not sending anyone soon. Due to timing keeping this lower than 50%.

To correct a misconception:
- An Article 7 motion "destroyer of rights, banisher of good faith, annihilator of voting rights" can just be vetoed by Poland, or by another country, and is unlikely to go through.
- An Article 7.1. determination, which is the step beforehand, just requires a 4/5ths majority: "the Council, acting by a majority of four-fifths of its members after obtaining the consent of the European Parliament, may determine..." This might be the equivalent of "alright, we're getting serious here, guys".

The question asks about a determination by the Council of the EU, ('CEU'), under Art 7.1 of the TEU/TFEU, [1]. In my opinion it is important to understand the procedure under that article of the Treaty.  It provides as follows: "1. On a reasoned proposal by one third of the Member States, by the European Parliament or by the European Commission, the Council, acting by a majority of four fifths of its members after obtaining the consent of the European Parliament, may determine that there is a clear risk of a serious breach by a Member State of the values referred to in Article 2. Before making such a determination, the Council shall hear the Member State in question and may address recommendations to it, acting in accordance with the same procedure.
The Council shall regularly verify that the grounds on which such a determination was made continue to apply." The trigger condition has already been met. Now, the question ask if 'the Council, acting by a majority of four fifths of its members after obtaining the consent of the European Parliament, may determine that there is a clear risk of a serious breach by a Member State of the values referred to in Article 2.' So, there needs to be consent of the EP.  That is likely to be given, having regard to the fact that the EP is considerably more active (and less constrained) on this issue, [2]. There also needs to be a majority of four/fifths of the members. (Poland and Hungary would vote for each other, [3], but that even with the rest of the Visegard group would not be enough, [4] . Finally, 'The Council shall regularly verify that the grounds on which such a determination was made continue to apply.'   This later point may provide an excuse for the Council IF Hungary has removed the emergency measures by the time of any Council determination.  It is clear that the Council is reluctant to condemn Hungary.  It has excuses available to it that would allow it to avoid doing so and/or to say that the situation no longer pertains which led to the reference, [3] Moreover, the Council struggles when it does not meet in person, [5]. Given that there has been no determination against Poland yet, or against Hungary in respect of the original reason for raising Art 7, despite the passage of years [6], [7] - amidst the Coronavirus crisis and the aftermath - I believe the Council will struggle to make space, or want to make space, for a divisive vote that might see Poland and Hungary try to leave the EU.   [1] https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A12012M%2FTXT
[2] https://www.euractiv.com/section/future-eu/news/sassoli-shows-his-differences-with-von-der-leyen-over-hungary/
[3] https://www.ft.com/content/91b124ed-5732-46b7-b589-28bf02553cf4
[4] https://www.dw.com/en/what-is-article-7-of-the-eu-treaty/a-41876855
[5] https://www.economist.com/europe/2020/04/11/how-to-run-a-continent-via-videolink
[6] https://polandin.com/47550324/analysis-ec-intervention-over-polish-presidential-election-likely "Article 7 of the same treaty gives the European Commission the power to activate proceedings that could lead to the suspension of a member state from voting right and for financial sanctions to be imposed on that country. Such proceedings have been activated, but have gone nowhere for the lack of unanimity among the member states. "  Note that the article suggests the proceedings before the CJEU were a response to the lack of action in Council.
[7] https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/agenda/briefing/2020-01-13/4/hungary-and-poland-parliament-to-assess-progress-of-article-7-proceedings

Everyone is busy managing the COVID19 crisis, except Sweden, so the Council will not move on this issue until the earliest next year. It is important and significant to move on the issue but not immediately pressing..
The question says make a determination, not actually do anything, so that's quite possible.

Seems if it needs to be unanimous then Poland and other eastern european countries can prevent this being passed. Very low base rate (has this ever been used before? from my searches it seems not) make me shy towards the lower end on this question.

A few things to note:  1) Parliament has passed an Article 7.1 infringement against Hungary before but the issue has STILL not been resolved at Council level so a determination has never been completed before.  2) The EPP recently chose to keep Fidesz in the party - although this was before Orban's latest shenanigans. 3) Only 4/5ths of Council members need to vote to approve recommendations - Visegrad bloc wouldn't be able to veto if all others were onside.  4) The EP recently passed a resolution urging the Council to put Article 7 proceedings back on the agenda.  In theory, the EP doesn't have to pass another resolution in order for the Council to make a determination against Hungary although another one would probably pass anyway. I'm minded to believe that an Article 7.1 determination will happen but I'm not sure it will in the timeframe laid out in this question. The real question here is whether or not there is enough initiative in the Council to proceed with the charges against Hungary. The ECJ has recently ruled that Hungary broke EU law on asylum policy so there is a legal justification already there. I think the crowd is too low on the chances of this happening. In theory only one more stage needs to be completed, it's whether or not there is a will to do so. I don't think there will be sufficient will in the timeframe so I think this is unlikely to happen. Not many Article 7 issues have happened before in the EU and none have ever led to sanction or even recommendation but if Article 7.1 existed when Austria formed a far-right government they probably would have had a 7.1 determination so I'm going to use that as my base for this forecast (33%) and revise slightly upwards due to the political uncertainty right now - it's a very rough calculation but that's all I've got!
They definitely need to do this.  They won't.
Even the EPP starts to support this, finally.

Still a lot of months to go. A lot depends on the actions taken when the most severe consequences of Covid-19 are over.  Orban deprived the parliament of its power [4]. If he does not reverse this decision, there will be an Article 7.1 determination of breaching EU values for sure.
Even if he reverse this particular decision, the times may be changing. You need 4/5 of EU countries to agree to determine Hungary is in breach [1, 3]. This means you need 21 countries (out of the 27 minus 1 countries) for an agreement. So even if the Visegrad states (Poland, Czech Republic, Slovakia and Hungary) do not vote in favour of an Article 7.1 determination of breach, it will go through. It is, however, not impossible that another state such as Malta that also shows issues with the rule of law will disagree as well [2]. [4] https://www.politico.eu/article/hungary-viktor-orban-rule-by-decree/

Background on triggering Article 7.1: Article 7.1: The mechanism begins with a proposal to find a "Clear Risk of Serious Breach" of EU values either by the Commission, the Parliament or one-third of member states. This is then approved by a two-thirds majority in Parliament. The accused country is then called to answer to the Council, which may then issue recommendations and vote by four-fifths to identify a breach.  Covid-19 and it’s responses from various EU governments have been drastic during the crisis. Inward facing difficulties combined with long term implications is highly likely to shift focus away from policing member states. Even if proceeds were to be considered, there is due process to be done which is difficult and time consuming - especially in the current circumstances. The threat of a second or third rise in cases globally during post measure lockdowns and autumn/winter is likely to prolong proceedings further.
